abstract: On rooftops, balconies, sidewalks and streets, the traditional sukkah, recalling Israelites' wandering in the desert, changes the face of New York neighborhoods.
snippet: On rooftops, balconies, sidewalks and streets, the traditional sukkah, recalling Israelites' wandering in the desert, changes the face of New York neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: It is possible, in many parts of New York, to pass through autumn unaware of the Jewish festival of Sukkot. It is, however, impossible to pass through Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg, Crown Heights and Borough Park without knowing that the eight-day harvest holiday is under way.

headline.main: With Bamboo Roofs and Plywood Walls, Williamsburg Is Transformed for Sukkot
